Award.AwardTitle: SHF: Large: Phase-Based Logic Realized Using Oscillatory Nanosystems (PHLOGON)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Exponential progress in Complementary Metal Oxide Semiconductor (CMOS) miniaturization (Moore's Law) over decades has increased computing power to the point that it has transformed science and engineering and touched every aspect of modern society. Continuing progress in computing at the same rate for several more decades is likely to have an even greater impact than that seen so far. Unfortunately, over the last decade, Moore's Law has become increasingly threatened by fundamental design and manufacturing limitations that are being reached. In particular, as individual CMOS logic elements have become smaller, they have also become more sensitive to noise and interference. Moreover, CMOS elements consume power disproportionate to their size; supplying this power, dissipating the heat generated, and containing the adverse effects of high temperatures all constitute serious roadblocks to Moore's Law.

This project on PHase based LOGic using Oscillatory Nano-systems (PHLOGON) aims to circumvent these problems via a fundamentally different physical paradigm for computing: the bits and bytes that constitute digital information are encoded using the phase (or timing) of oscillatory (i.e., undulating) signals, not as voltage levels as in conventional computing. Phase encoding has inherent noise immunity advantages over level encoding; PHLOGON exploits this feature fully within the most basic elements that store and manipulate data bits. The core of PHLOGON is logic made of self-sustaining nonlinear oscillators (i.e., elements that generate their own undulating signals, like pendulum clocks). Such oscillatory logic elements can be realized easily using not only CMOS transistors, but also devices from biology such as neurons and intracellular oscillators, from nanotechnology such as Spin Torque Nano Oscillators (STNO) and Micro/Nano-Electro-Mechanical (M/NEMS) resonators, and from optics such as lasers. Thus, PHLOGON enables a wide variety of novel "substrates" for computing. Importantly, several of these (e.g., CMOS and STNOs) offer the promise of dramatically lower power/energy consumption than conventional level-based logic. By developing the core knowledge required for phase-based alternatives to level-based computing to be viable, the PHLOGON project can have significant and wide-ranging impact, potentially reversing the slow-down in Moore's Law and enabling progress in the physical mechanisms that underlie computing for decades to come.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For more than 60 years, computing has relied on level-based logic - ie, the bits and bytes that underlie all digital computing have been represented using different levels of physical quantities like voltages and currents. In the 1950s, Eiichi Goto and John von Neumann showed how phases of oscillators (ie, the angle at which a pendulum or grandfather clock is at any instant - in other words,  timing) can instead be used, and even built machines based on this idea that were briefly commercially successful. But miniaturization via integrated circuits (ie, electronic chips) of their scheme was difficult, so these machines died out in the 1960s.

 

Our work in this project has shown that the schemes or Goto and von Neumann used (which were based on "parametric oscillators" that are hard to miniaturize) are not the only way phase-based computing can be implemented. Instead, a whole plethora of highly miniaturizable and nano-scale devices and circuits can be used, by relying on "self-sustaining oscillators" (of which grandfather clocks and metronomes are a perfect mechanical example, but such oscillators abound in electronics and nature (including biology), optics, chemistry and other physical disciplines). We have developed the idea completely (mathematics, design and physical demonstration using cheap miniaturizable electronics, and also with mechanical metronomes). We have shown that the scheme is not only practical today, but is also attractive from the point of view of robustness to disturbances and noise, energy consumption and raw speed of operation.

 

Moreover, our project has had two unexpected side-effects:

1. We have shown mathematically that many interacting oscillators can behave as one single oscillator. This fact has been observed before, (especially in biology, eg, in the study of sleep/wake cycles), but never been properly understood prior to our work. Because our results provide precise and detailed insights into how oscillators group together into an equivalent oscillator (including via computational means), this result could possibly find application in broad fields - for example, it can be used to understand, and possibly work around, serious medical issues like Advanced/Delayed Sleep Phase Disorder.

2. Very near the end of the project, we discovered that oscillators can be put together to compute in a very different way from "regular digital computing" (more precisely, the von Neumann model of computing). They naturally implement so-called Ising Machines, which are devices that can effectively solve very difficult problems that challenge regular digital computers greatly. Further development of oscillator based Ising Machines can have a very great impact on every aspect of modern technological society, eg, by greatly increasing the capabilities of cellphones, to making logistics (Fedex, Amazon, airlines) dramatically easier and cheaper to figure out.
